name: Battle River #3
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1969, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 149 megawatts.,

name: Battle River #4
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1975, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 155 megawatts.

name: Battle River #5
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1981, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 385 megawatts.

name: Genesee #1
info: Genesee power station unit 1 has been in operation since 1994, and is one section of a 2 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts. They also have a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

name: Genesee #2
info: Genesee power station unit 2 has been in operation since 1994, and is one section of a 2 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts. They also have a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

name: Genesee #3
info: Genesee power station unit 3 has been in operation since 2005, and is one of the most advanced, fuel-efficient, and environmentally-progressive coal-fired facilities in Canada. It has a maximum capacity of 466 megawatts. It is also Canada's first power generation facility to use supercritical combustion technology for greater fuel efficiency and lower emissions.

name: H.R. Milner
info: Has been in operation since 1972, and uses a dual fuel steam turbine generator capable of burning both natural gas and coal. It has a maximum capacity of 144 megawatts.

name: Keephills #1
info: Keephills #1 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a 3 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395 megawatts

name: Keephills #2
info: Keephills #2 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a 3 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395 megawatts

name: Keephills #3
info: Keephills #3 has been in operation since 2011, and is one of Canada’s largest and cleanest coal-fired facilities and one of the most advanced facilities of its kind in the world. And was built to replace the previously existing Wabamun 4 station

name: Sheerness #1
location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
info: It has been in operation since 1986, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts, and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

name: Sheerness #2
location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
info: It has been in operation since 1990, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts, and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

name: Sundance #3
info: Was built in 1976 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 368 megawatts.

name: Sundance #4
info: Was built in 1977 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406 megawatts.

name: Sundance #5
info: Was built in 1978 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406 megawatts.

name: Sundance #6
info: Was built in 1980 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 401 megawatts.

name: Bighorn Hydro
info: Has been in operation since 1972, and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 120 megawatts.

name: Bow River Hydro
info: Was built in 1954, and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 320 megawatts.

name: Brazeau Hydro
info: Was built in 1965 and is Transalta's biggest hydro plant. it is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 350 megawatts

name: CUPC Oldman River
info: Was built is 2003 and was selected by Alberta Environment to develop the project at the existing dam site near Pincher Creek. it has a maximum capacity of 32

name: Chin Chute
info: a small scale irrigation pipe turbine, with a maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

name: Dickson Dam
info: It was built in 1992, the dam was created to control for floods and low winter flows, to improve quality of the river, to create a recreational resource and to provide a reliable, year-round water supply sufficient for future industrial, regional and municipal growth. it has a maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

name: Irrican Hydro
info: It was built in 1896, and is a small scale run-of-canal hydro plant in southern Alberta on the St. Mary’s Irrigation System.

name: Raymond Reservoir
info: A small hydro plant located beside the Raymond Reservoir, it was built in 1994. And has a maximum capacity of 21 megawatts.

name: Taylor Hydro
info: It was built in 2000, and operates during the six-month irrigation season each year from April to October. it has a maximum capcity of 14 megawatts.

name: Ardenville Wind
info: It was built in 2010 and is comprised of 23 80m wind turbines. It has a maximum capacity of 167 megawatts

name: BUL1 Bull Creek
info: It was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines, with a combined maximum capacity of 29 megawatts.

name: BUL2 Bull Creek
info: It was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines, with a combined maximum capacity of 29 megawatts.

name: Blackspring Ridge
info: It was built in 2014 and is comprised of 166 turbines, and is the largest investment of renewable energy in western Canada. And a maximum capacity of 300 megawatts.

name: Blue Trail Wind
info: Blue Trail was built in 2009, and is comprised of 22, 3 megawatt towers. It has a total maximum capacity of 167 megawatts.

name: Castle River #1
info: Castle River began operating in 1997 with more units being installed between 2000 and 2001. It is comprised of 60 turbines and seven addition turbnes located nearby. With a total maximum capacity of 44 megawatts.

name: Castle Rock Wind Farm
info: Began operation in 2012, and is comprised of 33 turbines, with a total maximum capacity of 77 megawatts.  Castle Rok Wind Farm will allow for over 130,000 tonnes of CO2 to be avoided.

name: Cowley Ridge
info: Cowley Ridge wind farm was decommissioned in the spring of 2016.

name: Enmax Taber
info: The Taber Wind farm has been in operation since 2007, it is comprised of 37 Enercon turibines, which is one of the most sofisticated turbine in the world. It has a total maximum capacity of 81 megawatts.

name: Ghost Pine
info: Ghost Pine Wind farm was built in 2010, it is comprised of 51 turbines, capable of generating enough power for 24, 300 homes. it has a total maximum capacity of 82 megawatts.

name: Halkirk Wind Power Facility
info: Built in 2012, it is comprised of 83 Vestas-Canadian Wind Technology Inc. turbines. it has a total maximum capacity of 150 megawatts.

name: Kettles Hill
info: Built in 2 phases spread over 2016 and 2017. it contains 35 turbines. with a total maximum capacity of 63 megawatts.

name: McBride Lake Windfarm
info: Built in 2003, it has 114 Vesta turbines. and creates enough electricity, to reduce carbon dioxide emmissions by 164,500 tonnes annually. It has a total maximum capacity of 75 megawatts.

name: Oldman 2 Wind Farm 1
info: Built in 2004, Ownership transitioned over to IKEA group in 2014, as part of their initiative to has a carbon footprint of zero. it has a total maximum capacity to 46 megawatts.

name: Soderglen Wind
info: Built in 2006, it is compirsed of  47 turbines, each 65 metres tall. it has a total maximum capacity of 71 megawatts.

name: Summerview 1
info: Built in 2004, it is comprised of 33 67 metre turbines. it has a total maximum capacity of 66 megawatts. and an active contract until 2033.

name: Summerview 2
info: Built in 2010, it is unit 2 of 2 for the summerview project. Comprised of 22 turbines, it has a total maximum capacity of 66 megawatts.

name: Suncor Chin Chute
info: Built in 2006, and with 20 turbines. The Chin Chute wind farm has the capability of generating power of 11,000 homes. and has a total maximum capacity of 30 megawatts.
owner: suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

name: Suncor Magrath
info: Built in 2004, with 20 turbines. it is capable of offsetting 70,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year. And has a maximum capacity of 30 megawatts.
owner: Suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

name: Wintering Hills
info: Built in 2011, Wintering Hills is comprised of 55 turbines. And has a total maximum capacity of 88 megawatts.

name: APF Athabasca
info: Was built in 1993 and continued operation until 2012, it had a maximum capacity of 131 megawatts. and is a biomass plant.

name: Brooks Solar
info: Built in 2017, Brooks 1 will include 50,000 solar panels, and will be western Canada's first utility scale solar project. It will have to maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

name: Cancarb Medicine Hat
info: Cancarb is a leader in the development and manufacturing of Thermal Carbon black. The plant has a maximum capacity of 42 megawatts.

name: DAI1 Daishowa
info: As a branch of Diashowa pulp factory, it is a biomass plant. And it has a maximum capacity of 52 megawatts.

name: Gold Creek Facility

name: Grande Prairie EcoPower
info: Built in 2005, it is a biomass plant, and has a maximum capacity of 25 megawatts.

name: NRGreen
info: Operating as a heat recovery plant, it works along the alliance pipline, and works in conjunction with 5 other similar plants. it has a maximum capacity of 16 megawatts.

name: Slave Lake
info: With the use of methane production from the pulp production, the slave lake pulp mill is able to create up to 6 megawatts of power.

name: Weldwood #1

name: Westlock
info: Built in 1997, it utilizes used woody biomass material to create a maximum of 46 megawatts.

name: Weyerhaeuser
info: Built as a section of the Grande Praire pul mill, it utilizes the waste from the mill, to create power from biomass. It has a maximum capacity of 48 megawatts.

name: Whitecourt Power
info: Built in 2012, Whitecourt powers biomass plant has earned the federal governments EcoLogo designation. It has a maximum capacity of 25 megawatts.

name: AB Newsprint
info: This facility has a generating capacity of 65 MW.

name: AltaGas Bantry

info: Parkland ses natural gas fired electrical peaking generators and total maximum capacity of 10MW

info: Built in 2015 with a total capacity of 5.6 MW.

name: Carson Creek

info: One of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

info: This facaility has a capacity of approximately 500 MW.

info: constructed to provide steam and electricity to meet the thermal and power needs of the Athabasca Oilsands Upgrader. two thirds of the power is used for the oilsands, with the surplus being sold to Alberta Power pool. with a maximum capacity of 195 megawatts.

info: A gas power plant, with a maximum capacity of 96 megawatts.

info: The Harmattan Gas Processing Complex processes and extracts gas. It is one of the largest gas plants in Alberta. And has a maximum capacity of 45 megawatts.

name: Base Plant
info: Located at Suncor's oilsands, it has a maximum capacity of 50 megawatts.

name: Bear Creek 1
info: Is a combined-cycle cogeneration with steam augmentation from a wood waste boiler. It has a maximum capacity of 64 megawatts.

name: Bear Creek 2
info: Is a combined-cycle cogeneration with steam augmentation from a wood waste boiler. It has a maximum capacity of 64 megawatts.

name: CNRL Horizon
info: Has a maximum capacity of 203 megawatts.

name: Camrose
info: Has a maximum capacity of 10 megawatts.

info: A cogeneration plant that supplies Alberta with up to 95 megawatts.

name: Christina Lake
info: Using cogeneration it has a maximum capacity of 100 megawatts.

name: Dow Hydrocarbon
info: with the main focus being on turning crude oil and natural gas based raw material into basic chemical building blocks and intermediate products for Dow's downstream derivative partners. Has a maximum capacity of 326 megawatts.

name: Edson
info: In the process of being improved upon, this plant will eventually be able to produce 900 megawatts of power. but at the moment has a maximum capacity of 13 megawatts.

name: Firebag
info: Built in 2003, the firebag plant has a maximum capacity of 473 megawatts. and is one on the few power plants located north of the 56th parallel.

name: Fort Hills
info: capable of sustaining a production of 14,500 tonnes of oil sand per hour, and with a maximum capacity of 199 megawatts. Fort Hills is located on the Athabasca oil sands.

name: Foster Creek
info: As Cenovus's first oil sand project, they make use of technology called steam-assisted gravity drainage (SAGD), to drill and pump the oil to the surface. it has a maximum capacity of 98 megawatts.

name: Joffre #1
info: Is a natural gas-fired cogeneration plant to meet the substantial steam and electric energy needs of NOVA’s world-class petrochemical facility, selling excess power in the Alberta power pool. has a maximum capacity of 474 megawatts.

name: Kearl
info: The Kearl oilsands are located near the Athanbasca oilsands, and has a maximum capacity of 84 megawatts.

name: Lindbergh
info: Built in 2012 as a steam injection pilot project. it has a maximum capacity of 16 megawatts.

name: MEG1 Christina Lake
info: A Canadian oil sands company focused on sustainable in situ development and production in the Southern Athabasca region of Alberta. Has a maximum capacity of 202 megawatts.

name: MacKay River
info: MacKay River is an industrial cogeneration project that is situated on Suncor’s MacKay River oilsands development. it has a maximum capacity of 207 megawatts.

name: Mahkeses
info: Opened for production in the 1960's it is one Canada's oldest power plants and one of the largest thermal in-situ heavy oil operations in the world. it has a maximum capacity of 180 megawatts.

name: Muskeg River
info: Is a  cogeneration plant provides steam and electricity to meet the requirements of the Muskeg River Mine. Any electricity generated and not used at the mine is sold into the Power Pool of Alberta. it has a maximum capacity of 202 megawatts.

name: Nabiye
info: Built in 2004, as a part of Imperial Oil 13 phase bitimun production. it has a maximum capacity of 195 megawatts.

name: Nexen Inc #2
info: Has a maximum capacity of 220 megawatts.

name: Poplar Creek
info: Poplar Creek is gas-fired turbines at Suncor’s oil sands site near Fort McMurray. TransAlta provides Suncor with centralized monitoring, diagnostics and technical support to maximize performance and reliability of plant equipment. it has a maximum capacity of 376 megawatts.

name: Primrose #1
info: Primrose has a maximum capacity of 100 megawatts and was Alberta’s first independent power project on stream in 1998 in the newly deregulated market.

name: Rainbow Lake #1
info: has since been decommissioned as of November 2016

name: Redwater Cogen
info: The plant is customized to use a blend of natural gas and regeneration gas, a product of Williams Energy’s fractionation business, to fuel the gas turbine, and has a maximum capacity of 46 megawatts.

name: Shell Caroline
info: Is part of the Shell Caroline Complex, and has a maximum capacity of 19 megawatts.

name: Syncrude #1
info: As one of the biggest operators in Canada's Oil sands it creates up to 510 megawatts of power for Alberta.

name: U of C Generator
info: The university cogeneration plant will allow for the university to cut its CO2 emissions by half. and has a maximum capacity of 12 megawatts.

name: University of Alberta
info: Has a maximum capacity of 39 megawatts, and is used to heat the campus buildings.

name: ENMAX Calgary Energy Centre
info: The Calgary Energy Center is a combined cycle powerplant located on the northeast corner of Calgary Alberta. Powered by a single Westinghouse W502-FD2 combustion turbine. and has a maximum capacity of 320 megawatts.

name: Cavalier
info: The Cavalier Energy Centre and the Balzac Facility are part of a larger generation portfolio intended to help meet the growing electricity needs of our customers across Alberta. And has a maximum capacity of 120 megawatts.

name: Fort Nelson
info: Another of BC Hydro's alternative energy sources is thermal generation. This involves burning fuel to produce hot gases or steam to drive gas or steam turbines that are connected to generators. with a maximum capacity of 73 megawatts being sent to Alberta.

name: Medicine Hat #1
info: Opened in 2017, it is used to supply power to the city. it has a maximum capacity of 255 megawatts.

name: Nexen Inc #1
info: The Balzac Power Station is a natural gas-fired combined cycle, power generation facility capable of producing up to 120 megawatts, approximately enough to power 100,000 residential homes

name: Shepard
info: Shepard is now fully operational and is Alberta's largest natural gas-fuelled power facility. it has a maximum capacity of 860 megawatts.
